intro: Carex michiganensis, commonly known as Michigan sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the northeastern United States. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and other grass-like plants. This plant typically grows in moist to wet soils, often found in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds. It has slender, triangular stems and produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various wildlife species.
